I understand why those details might seem puzzling at first glance - they're actually some of the most commonly raised questions about the moon landings, and they have solid explanations when you dig into the physics and photography involved.

The flag "waving" is actually a great example of how our Earth-based intuitions can mislead us. The flag had a horizontal rod along the top to keep it extended (since it wouldn't hang naturally in the moon's low gravity). When the astronauts planted it and adjusted it, the fabric moved and then stayed in those wrinkled positions because there's no air resistance to dampen the motion. It looks like waving to us because we're used to seeing fabric move that way in wind.

As for the stars - this is really about camera exposure. The lunar surface and the astronauts' white suits were incredibly bright in direct sunlight. The cameras were set to expose for these bright subjects, which meant the relatively dim stars were far too faint to register on the film. It's the same reason you can't see stars in photos of brightly lit cities at night.

What's compelling to me is that the Soviets - who had every incentive to expose a hoax - tracked and confirmed the missions. Also, we left retroreflectors on the moon that scientists still bounce lasers off today.
